intro: Euphrasia hudsoniana var. ramosior, commonly known as Hudson's beard-tongue, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Scrophulariaceae family and is characterized by its slender, hairy stems and clusters of small, showy flowers. The flowers typically bloom in late spring to early summer, featuring pink to purple petals with a distinctive yellow throat. The plant thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its foliage consists of opposite, ovate leaves with hairy surfaces, contributing to its overall ecological role in supporting pollinators.
